summary: An email chain from July 23, 2019, among Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York staff discussing an incident where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with marks on his neck in his cell. The emails detail the initial response, medical and psychological assessments, and plans for his housing, including a mention that Epstein's attorneys had visited.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Marks in Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He was found lying on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck, alleging his cellmate attempted to kill him. He was placed in restraints and on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical and Psychological Assessments
events.description: Epstein was medically assessed at 6:30 a.m. (noting erythema on neck and knee, but he was ambulatory and smiling) and psychologically evaluated at 9:10 a.m. (determined to remain on suicide watch).

events.title: Attorney Visits and Housing Review
events.description: Epstein's attorneys visited and signed in at 12:17 p.m. MCC staff reviewed his case for placement in general population (Unit 7 South) and sought an appropriate cellmate.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with red marks on his neck, alleging his cellmate attempted to kill him.

Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident, but a medical assessment noted he was 'ambulatory, oriented x 3... smiling during this clinical encounter' and denied pain or knowledge of the marks.
Epstein's attorneys had visited the facility on the same day, and he had previously informed them about harassment from his cellmate.
MCC staff were reviewing his case for placement in the general population (Unit 7 South) and seeking an appropriate cellmate at the time of the emails.
The email chain shows internal MCC communication regarding the incident, medical findings, and housing plans, intended for reporting to higher authorities like IPPA and the Director.
